[[File:Zuijlen van Nijevelt, PH baron van. Generaal.jpg|170px|thumb|Pieter Hendrik van Zuylen van Nijevelt]] '''Pieter Hendrik van Zuylen van Nijevelt''' (1 July 1782 in [[Kampen (Overijssel)|Kampen]] – 25 January 1825 in [[Utrecht (city)|Utrecht]]) was a [[Dutch people|Dutch]] count and baron who served as a general in the French and Dutch armies during the [[Napoleonic era]] and later. He was present at the [[Battle of Waterloo]] in 1815 as chief of staff of the 2nd Dutch Division.
Pieter Hendrik's son [[Julius van Zuylen van Nijevelt]] (1819–1894), born in Luxembourg, inherited his titles of count and baron. He served as prime minister of the Netherlands from 1866 to 1868.
==Early years == Pieter Hendrik van Zuylen van Nijevelt was a member of the prominent Rotterdam patrician (''[[regenten]]'') family of [[Van Zuylen van Nijevelt]]. He was the oldest son of [[Philip Julius van Zuylen van Nijevelt]] and Clara Helena de Wacker van Son. His father was a Dutch general who was appointed [[Marshal of Holland]] in the [[Kingdom of Holland]], served as [[Sénat conservateur|French senator]] following the annexation of Holland by the [[Napoleonic Empire]], and was named ''comte de l'Empire'' by [[Napoleon]].<ref name="nationaalarchief">[http://www.nationaalarchief.nl/toegangen/pdf/NL-HaNA_2.21.181.ead.pdf Nationaal Archief] (Dutch)</ref>
==Napoleonic era== During the Napoleonic era, he served in the [[Dutch Brigade (Peninsular War)|Dutch brigade]] on the French side in the [[Peninsular War]] from 1808 to 1810; at the [[Battle of Ocaña]] (1809), he was a captain. Van Zuylen van Nijevelt also served in the French armed forces in Germany and Russia. At the age of 30, he was promoted to the rank of adjutant general.<ref name="herinneringen">[http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/_ned017198001_01/_ned017198001_01_0013.php#995T Julius van Zuylen van Nijevelt, "Herinneringen uit mijn leven. Opgedragen aan mijn beminde kinderen". In C. Dekker et al. (eds.), ''Nederlandse historische bronnen'', vol. 2. Martinus Nijhoff, Den Haag 1980, pp. 217-219] (Dutch)</ref>
Following the restoration of the [[House of Orange-Nassau]] in the Netherlands in 1813, he joined the Dutch armed forces with the rank of colonel (as the rank of adjutant general did not exist in the Dutch army). In the [[Battle of Quatre Bras]] and the [[Battle of Waterloo]] (1815), Pieter Hendrik served on the allied side as chief of staff of the 2nd Dutch Division under the command of [[Hendrik George de Perponcher Sedlnitsky|Perponcher]]. In recognition of his service at Waterloo, he received the [[Military William Order]] and was promoted to the rank of general.<ref name="herinneringen"/>
==United Kingdom of the Netherlands== In 1817 he married his niece, the baroness Susanna Martha van Zuylen van Nijevelt (1787–1831). They moved to [[Luxembourg]] where he served as Dutch military commander. In Luxembourg, Pieter Hendrik frequently came into conflict with the [[Prussia]]n military, who garrisoned the fortress of Luxembourg.<ref name="herinneringen"/>
He left Luxembourg in 1824 for Utrecht, where he lived in a house on Plompetorengracht canal. There he died in 1825, at the age of only 42 — a year before the death of his father.<ref name="herinneringen" />
